title: Ezekiel Chapter 26 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 26 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 26 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 26.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 26:2, what city is speaking against Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Tyrus
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:2 says, 'because that Tyrus hath said against Jerusalem...'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 26:3, what will the Lord do against Tyrus?
options: Cause many nations to come up against it
questions.correctAnswer: Cause many nations to come up against it
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:3 states, 'I am against thee, O Tyrus, and will cause many nations to come up against thee...'

questions.question: What will happen to the walls and towers of Tyrus according to Ezekiel 26:4?
options: They will be destroyed and broken down
questions.correctAnswer: They will be destroyed and broken down
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:4 says, 'They shall destroy the walls of Tyrus, and break down her towers...'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 26:5 states that Tyrus shall be a place for the spreading of ______.
questions.correctAnswer: nets
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:5 says, 'It shall be a place for the spreading of nets in the midst of the sea.'

questions.question: Who is prophesied to come against Tyrus as described in Ezekiel 26:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:7 states, 'I will bring upon Tyrus Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon...'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 26:9, what will Nebuchadrezzar use against Tyrus' walls?
questions.correctAnswer: Engines of war and axes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:9 says, 'He shall set engines of war against thy walls, and with his axes he shall break down thy towers.'

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 26:11 says Nebuchadrezzar will spare the streets of Tyrus.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:11 says, 'With the hoofs of his horses shall he tread down all thy streets...'

questions.question: What will happen to the riches and merchandise of Tyrus in Ezekiel 26:12?
options: They shall be made spoil and prey
They shall be given as gifts
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be made spoil and prey
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:12 says, 'They shall make a spoil of thy riches, and make a prey of thy merchandise.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 26:13, what will happen to the noise of Tyrus' songs?
options: It will be heard throughout the land
It will be changed to weeping
questions.correctAnswer: It will cease
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:13 states, 'I will cause the noise of thy songs to cease; and the sound of thy harps shall be no more heard.'

questions.question: What will Tyrus become like, according to Ezekiel 26:14?
questions.correctAnswer: The top of a rock
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:14 says, 'I will make thee like the top of a rock... thou shalt be built no more.'

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 26:15 says the isles will rejoice at the fall of Tyrus.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:15 states, 'Shall not the isles shake at the sound of thy fall,' indicating they will tremble, not rejoice.

questions.question: Who will come down from their thrones and tremble at Tyrus, according to Ezekiel 26:16?
questions.correctAnswer: Princes of the sea
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:16 says, 'Then all the princes of the sea shall come down from their thrones... and shall tremble at every moment.'

questions.question: What will the princes of the sea do for Tyrus according to Ezekiel 26:17?
questions.correctAnswer: Take up a lamentation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:17 states, 'And they shall take up a lamentation for thee...'

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 26:18 says the isles will be troubled at Tyrus' departure.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:18 says, 'Now shall the isles tremble... shall be troubled at thy departure.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 26:21, what will happen to Tyrus after its destruction?
options: It shall be a terror and no more
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be a terror and no more
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:21 says, 'I will make thee a terror, and thou shalt be no more... yet shalt thou never be found again.'

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 26 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 26 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and boasting about their strength. Based on Ezekiel 26, what biblical truth would you share about relying on God?
options: Pride leads to destruction as God opposes the proud.
Boasting will ensure safety and success.
Strength comes from alliances with many nations.
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to destruction as God opposes the proud.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:2-4 shows how Tyrus boasted against Jerusalem, leading God to oppose it and promise its destruction. This teaches humility and trust in God's power rather than self-reliance.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 26 teach us about perseverance through trials when facing overwhelming opposition?
options: God controls the outcome even when many nations oppose us.
We must fight alone without trusting God.
Give up when trials become too hard.
questions.correctAnswer: God controls the outcome even when many nations oppose us.
questions.explanation: Verses 3-7 describe many nations coming against Tyrus as waves of the sea, but this is under God's sovereign control. Believers can persevere knowing God governs history.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by loss of resources and possessions. According to Ezekiel 26, what biblical principle about earthly riches would you encourage them with?
options: Earthly riches are temporary and can be lost by God's judgment.
Riches are a sign of spiritual superiority.
One should hoard wealth for security.
questions.correctAnswer: Earthly riches are temporary and can be lost by God's judgment.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:12 shows Tyrus’ riches and merchandise being spoiled and destroyed, emphasizing that material wealth is not reliable and God can remove it.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 26 encourage believers to trust God’s justice when facing enemies or betrayal?
options: God will bring judgment on enemies in His timing.
Justice depends on human power only.
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring judgment on enemies in His timing.
questions.explanation: Verses 7-11 describe Nebuchadnezzar’s coming against Tyrus as God's judgment. This shows God’s justice will prevail, encouraging believers to trust Him rather than retaliate impulsively.

questions.question: A fellow believer asks about contentment during loss. Based on Ezekiel 26, what biblical truth about contentment can you share?
options: Contentment is trusting God even when earthly things are destroyed.
Contentment depends on wealth and possessions.
Loss means God has abandoned us.
We must rebuild quickly at any cost.
questions.correctAnswer: Contentment is trusting God even when earthly things are destroyed.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:13-14 shows the destruction of Tyrus and cessation of its songs, yet God's words remain true. Believers can find contentment in God's sovereign plan despite loss.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 26 teach about humility and God’s sovereignty in life’s challenges?
options: God humbles the proud and shows His sovereignty over nations.
Human pride can overcome God’s plans.
God ignores the arrogance of cities.
questions.correctAnswer: God humbles the proud and shows His sovereignty over nations.
questions.explanation: Verses 15-18 describe the lamentation over Tyrus’ fall and the trembling of the isles, showing God's power to humble the proud and control nations.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 26 demonstrate the importance of obedience and trust in God’s Word?
options: God’s declarations come to pass, so obedience is essential.
Ignoring God’s Word has no consequences.
Trusting human wisdom is better than God’s Word.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s declarations come to pass, so obedience is essential.
questions.explanation: Verses 14 and 21 emphasize God’s spoken word about Tyrus’ destruction will surely happen, teaching believers that God’s Word is trustworthy and obedience is vital.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 26 teaches that God’s judgment can lead to complete desolation and removal of a city’s existence.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:19-21 describes Tyrus becoming a desolate city, covered by deep waters and never to be inhabited again, showing complete judgment and removal.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 26, God’s judgment is always harsh and without purpose.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: God’s judgment in Ezekiel 26 serves to demonstrate His holiness and sovereignty and to bring awareness that He is the LORD (Ezekiel 26:6, 26:21). It is purposeful, not arbitrary.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 26 says the city of Tyrus will be made like the top of a _______, a place to spread nets upon.
questions.correctAnswer: rock
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:4 and 26:14 both state that Tyrus will be scraped to the top of a rock and become a place to spread nets upon, symbolizing complete ruin.

questions.question: A believer is facing fear about future trials and opposition. Based on Ezekiel 26, what encouragement can you share about God’s control over such situations?
options: God causes many nations to come against the proud, but He is sovereign over all events.
Trials come by chance and are unpredictable.
Opposition means God is angry at you.
Rely on your own strength to overcome all trials.
questions.correctAnswer: God causes many nations to come against the proud, but He is sovereign over all events.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:3 describes God causing many nations to rise against Tyrus as waves of the sea, showing His control even in difficult circumstances.

questions.question: How does the destruction of Tyrus in Ezekiel 26 teach us about honesty and integrity in our work and dealings?
options: Dishonest pride and exploitation can lead to downfall under God’s judgment.
Success justifies any means including dishonesty.
Only wealth matters, not how it is obtained.
questions.correctAnswer: Dishonest pride and exploitation can lead to downfall under God’s judgment.
questions.explanation: Tyrus was a wealthy seafaring city boasting against Jerusalem (Ezekiel 26:2), and God’s judgment shows pride and exploitation bring ruin (26:12-14). This teaches the importance of honesty and integrity.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 26 teach about the importance of humility in family and church life?
options: Pride brings downfall, so humility preserves peace and fellowship.
Humility is irrelevant in communal life.
questions.correctAnswer: Pride brings downfall, so humility preserves peace and fellowship.
questions.explanation: The downfall of Tyrus due to pride (Ezekiel 26:2-4) illustrates the biblical principle that humility is essential for healthy relationships and community life.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling discouraged about their witness to others. According to Ezekiel 26, what biblical truth about God’s timing and purpose in evangelism can you share?
options: God’s timing is perfect and His judgment reveals His holiness, urging repentance.
Evangelism is ineffective against proud hearts.
God does not care about people’s response.
Only human effort matters in evangelism.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s timing is perfect and His judgment reveals His holiness, urging repentance.
questions.explanation: The judgment against Tyrus reveals God’s holiness and desire that nations know Him (Ezekiel 26:6, 21), showing that God’s timing in judgment and evangelism is part of His redemptive plan.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 26 illustrate the importance of prayer and dependence on God during times of spiritual attack?
options: The siege of Tyrus shows believers must rely on God’s intervention, not human strength.
Prayer is unnecessary when facing enemies.
Dependence on self is better than dependence on God.
questions.correctAnswer: The siege of Tyrus shows believers must rely on God’s intervention, not human strength.
questions.explanation: Verses 7-11 describe the overwhelming attack on Tyrus by Nebuchadnezzar, indicating that human power is insufficient and believers must trust in God’s intervention.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 26 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 26.

questions.question: What is the initial cause for the prophecy against Tyre in Ezekiel 26?
options: Tyre refused to trade with Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Tyre rejoiced over Jerusalem's destruction
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:2 states that Tyre said against Jerusalem, 'Aha, she is broken... I shall be replenished,' which provoked the prophecy against it.

questions.question: Who is prophesied to come against Tyre as a 'king of kings' in Ezekiel 26?
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:7 clearly identifies Nebuchadrezzar as the king of Babylon who will bring war upon Tyre.

questions.question: What imagery is used to describe the multitude of nations coming against Tyre?
options: As the sea causing its waves to come up
As a flock of birds migrating
As a fire consuming the forest
As a storm destroying a city
questions.correctAnswer: As the sea causing its waves to come up
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:3 uses the metaphor of the sea causing its waves to come up to depict many nations rising against Tyre.

questions.question: What is the fate of Tyre described in Ezekiel 26:4-5?
options: Its walls and towers will be destroyed and it will become a place for spreading nets
It will become the capital of Babylon
It will be rebuilt stronger than before
It will become a fertile land for agriculture
questions.correctAnswer: Its walls and towers will be destroyed and it will become a place for spreading nets
questions.explanation: Verses 4-5 state that Tyre’s walls and towers will be destroyed and it will become like the top of a rock, a place for spreading nets in the sea.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 26:13 prophesy about the cultural life of Tyre after its destruction?
options: The noise of songs and sound of harps will cease
Its festivals will become more prominent
It will produce renowned poets and musicians
questions.correctAnswer: The noise of songs and sound of harps will cease
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:13 says God will cause the noise of Tyre’s songs and harps to cease, indicating cultural desolation.

questions.question: Which military strategies are described in Ezekiel 26 regarding the siege of Tyre?
options: Setting up engines of war, casting a mount, and lifting up the buckler
Building a naval fleet to blockade the city
Using spies to infiltrate the city
questions.correctAnswer: Setting up engines of war, casting a mount, and lifting up the buckler
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:8-9 details the use of engines of war, building a mount, and raising shields against Tyre’s walls.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'like the top of a rock' symbolize in the prophecy against Tyre?
options: A place barren and exposed, where nets are spread
A place of strength and refuge
A mountain where the people will gather
A holy site consecrated to God
questions.correctAnswer: A place barren and exposed, where nets are spread
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:4 and 26:14 use this phrase to convey Tyre’s desolation and transformation into a place for fishermen’s nets.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 26, Tyre’s daughters in the field will be spared during the attack.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:6 states that Tyre’s daughters in the field shall be slain by the sword, indicating no mercy.

questions.question: What emotional reaction do the princes of the sea have to Tyre’s fall according to Ezekiel 26?
options: They tremble, lay aside their robes, and lament
They celebrate with feasting and dancing
They prepare for war against Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: They tremble, lay aside their robes, and lament
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:16-17 describes the princes of the sea trembling, removing their royal garments, and mourning Tyre’s destruction.

questions.question: Which phrase best captures the theological theme in Ezekiel 26:6 and 26:11 about God's sovereignty?
options: 'They shall know that I am the LORD'
'The city of Tyre shall rise again'
questions.correctAnswer: 'They shall know that I am the LORD'
questions.explanation: This phrase appears in 26:6 and the chapter overall emphasizes God’s sovereign judgment on Tyre.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 26 foreshadow the historical siege by Alexander the Great?
options: By describing Tyre as a rock in the sea and unbuilt again, which matches Alexander's siege and destruction
By predicting the destruction of Babylon
By mentioning Egyptian forces attacking Tyre
By prophesying the rise of Rome
questions.correctAnswer: By describing Tyre as a rock in the sea and unbuilt again, which matches Alexander's siege and destruction
questions.explanation: The description in Ezekiel 26:4-5 and 14 about Tyre’s desolation and being a place for spreading nets aligns with historical accounts of Alexander’s siege.

questions.question: Which Old Testament book also contains a prophecy about Tyre’s downfall that echoes Ezekiel 26?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 23 contains a prophecy against Tyre that parallels Ezekiel 26’s themes of destruction and desolation.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 26:19-20, what is the symbolic significance of 'bringing up the deep' and 'great waters' upon Tyre?
options: Symbolizing complete destruction and submersion under the judgment of God
Depicting a military alliance with sea nations
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolizing complete destruction and submersion under the judgment of God
questions.explanation: The imagery of deep waters covering Tyre in Ezekiel 26:19-20 symbolizes overwhelming judgment and desolation.

questions.question: What is the literary function of the lamentation over Tyre in Ezekiel 26:17-18?
options: To emphasize the city’s former glory and the tragedy of its fall
To illustrate the power of Babylon
To introduce a new prophecy about Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: To emphasize the city’s former glory and the tragedy of its fall
questions.explanation: The lament in Ezekiel 26:17-18 highlights Tyre’s prominence and the sorrow caused by its destruction, enhancing the pathos of the prophecy.

questions.question: Which Hebrew term translated as 'engines of war' in Ezekiel 26:9 reflects ancient siege technology?
questions.correctAnswer: Catapults or battering rams
questions.explanation: The term translated as 'engines of war' refers to siege equipment such as battering rams employed to break down walls in ancient warfare.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 26 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 26 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason God declares judgment against Tyre in Ezekiel 26?
options: Tyre allied with Babylon against Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Tyre rejoiced over Jerusalem's destruction
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:2 states that Tyre said 'Aha, she is broken, that was the gates of the people,' expressing joy over Jerusalem's desolation. This reveals God's judgment against pride and rejoicing over the downfall of His people, consistent with Proverbs 24:17 and Obadiah 1:12.

questions.question: Which king does God raise up to bring judgment upon Tyre according to Ezekiel 26?
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:7 identifies Nebuchadrezzar, king of Babylon, as the instrument of God's judgment on Tyre, emphasizing God's sovereignty over nations (Daniel 4:17, Isaiah 45:1, Romans 13:1).

questions.question: What imagery does God use to describe the nations coming against Tyre?
options: As a lion stalking its prey
questions.correctAnswer: As waves of the sea
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:3 compares the nations rising against Tyre to the sea causing its waves to come up, demonstrating the unstoppable and overwhelming nature of divine judgment, paralleling Revelation 17:15 and Psalm 89:9.

questions.question: What will God make Tyre like after its destruction?
questions.correctAnswer: The top of a rock
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:4 and 26:14 say God will make Tyre like the top of a rock, symbolizing desolation and inability to be rebuilt, reflecting God's judgment and the permanence of divine decrees (Jeremiah 49:16, Isaiah 2:10).

questions.question: What will become of Tyre’s daughters in the field according to Ezekiel 26?
options: They shall be slain by the sword
They will escape to another land
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be slain by the sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:6 and 26:8 indicate that the daughters (colonies or allies) of Tyre will be slain by the sword, underscoring the comprehensive nature of God's judgment on the city and its dependencies (2 Kings 19:26, Isaiah 37:28).

questions.question: What military actions are described against Tyre’s defenses?
options: Breaking down walls and towers with axes and engines of war
Sieging the city without breaking walls
questions.correctAnswer: Breaking down walls and towers with axes and engines of war
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:9 describes the breaking down of walls and towers by engines of war and axes, illustrating the total military destruction decreed by God (Joshua 6:20, 2 Chronicles 32:5).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 26 describe the impact of the invading army’s horses on Tyre?
options: Their dust covers the city and their noise shakes the walls
They are defeated by Tyre's archers
questions.correctAnswer: Their dust covers the city and their noise shakes the walls
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:10 depicts the horses' dust covering Tyre and the noise of horsemen shaking the walls, signifying overwhelming power and terror, consistent with Zechariah 1:8 and Revelation 6:2.

questions.question: What will happen to Tyre's riches and merchandise according to Ezekiel 26?
options: They will be taken as spoil and prey by the nations
They will be hidden and protected
They will be preserved as a holy offering
They will be destroyed by fire
questions.correctAnswer: They will be taken as spoil and prey by the nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:12 states that Tyre's riches and merchandise will be made spoil and prey, illustrating the judgment on material pride and security (Isaiah 33:1, Jeremiah 6:26).

questions.question: What will happen to the sound of Tyre’s songs and harps?
options: They will cease and no longer be heard
They will echo throughout the land
They will inspire hope in the captives
They will be transformed into prayers
questions.correctAnswer: They will cease and no longer be heard
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:13 declares that the noise of songs and harps will cease, symbolizing the silencing of joy and celebration due to divine judgment, reflecting Lamentations 2:6 and Amos 5:23.

questions.question: What prophetic imagery is used to describe the reaction of the isles and princes of the sea to Tyre’s fall?
options: They will tremble, lay aside their robes, and lament
They will seek to conquer the ruins
questions.correctAnswer: They will tremble, lay aside their robes, and lament
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:15-17 describe the isles and sea princes trembling, removing their royal garments, and lamenting Tyre’s destruction, indicating the widespread impact and awe of God's judgment (Isaiah 24:17, Revelation 18:9-10).

questions.question: How does God describe the future habitation status of Tyre after judgment?
options: It will be desolate and not inhabited
It will be repopulated by foreigners
It will be restored to its former glory
It will become a center of worship
questions.correctAnswer: It will be desolate and not inhabited
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:19 and 26:20 affirm that Tyre will become a desolate city, uninhabited and covered by waters, symbolizing irrevocable judgment and desolation, consistent with Isaiah 6:11 and Jeremiah 25:12.

questions.question: What ultimate fate does God declare for Tyre in Ezekiel 26:21?
options: It will be made a terror and never be found again
It will become a place of refuge
It will be a symbol of God's mercy
It will be rebuilt by the exiles
questions.correctAnswer: It will be made a terror and never be found again
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:21 states God will make Tyre a terror and it will never be found again, emphasizing the finality and completeness of divine judgment, paralleling the fate of Babylon (Isaiah 13:19, Jeremiah 51:37).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 26, what divine attribute is prominently revealed through the judgment on Tyre?
options: God's sovereignty over nations and judgment upon pride
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereignty over nations and judgment upon pride
questions.explanation: The passage shows God's sovereign control over kings and nations to execute judgment on Tyre's pride and rejoicing over Jerusalem (Ezekiel 26:3, 7, Romans 13:1, Proverbs 16:18, Isaiah 2:12).

questions.question: What theological truth about God’s justice is illustrated by God using Nebuchadrezzar to punish Tyre?
options: God uses worldly powers to accomplish His righteous judgment
God acts only through direct supernatural means
God’s justice is arbitrary and unpredictable
questions.correctAnswer: God uses worldly powers to accomplish His righteous judgment
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 26:7 shows God raising Nebuchadrezzar to bring judgment, illustrating that God sovereignly uses earthly rulers and powers to fulfill His justice (Daniel 4:17, Romans 13:1-4, Isaiah 10:5-7).

questions.question: What eschatological theme can be seen in the depiction of Tyre’s destruction and desolation?
options: Final judgment and the removal of evil from the earth
The eternal reign of Tyre as a kingdom
The restoration of Tyre as a holy city
The universal salvation of all nations
questions.correctAnswer: Final judgment and the removal of evil from the earth
questions.explanation: The total destruction and desolation of Tyre (Ezekiel 26:19-21) reflect the biblical theme of final judgment where evil is removed, consistent with Revelation 18 and Isaiah 66:24.
